Class JsCharacterData

java.lang.Object
  js.Disposable
      js.Var<JsObject>
          js.core.JsObject
              js.dom.DOM2Core.Node.Prototype
                  js.user.JsNode
                      js.dom.DOM2Core.CharacterData.Prototype
                          js.user.JsCharacterData
All Implemented Interfaces:
ObjectLike
Direct Known Subclasses:
DOM2Core.Comment.Prototype, DOM2Core.Text.Prototype
public class JsCharacterData
extends DOM2Core.CharacterData.Prototype

An opaque class representing JavaScript client-side objects of the global JsClient.CharacterData class.

This class defines functionality for its subclasses JsText and JsComment.

Note that it is not necessary to use the string-manipulation methods defined by this class. The data property is of string type, and you can manipulate it with various string and regular expression methods.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org
JavaScript:
Opaque types can be resolved but no class objects for them can be generated into the target codes. Re-compilers must exit with error on the operations of accessing that kind of class objects. The checkcast operation to the class literal of this interface must be ignored and instanceof to it always true.

Field Detail

data

public static final Value.String.Member data

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsCharacterData node object refers to the text value contained by the node.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

appendData

public final void appendData(java.lang.String arg)

Appends the specified string to the text contained by this node.

This method appends the string arg to the end of the data property for the current node.

Parameters:
arg - The string to be appended to the current node.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if this method was called on a node that is read-only and may not be modified. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

deleteData

public final void deleteData(java.lang.Number offset,
                             java.lang.Number count)

Deletes text from the current node, starting with the character at the specified offset and continuing for the specified number of characters.

This method deletes characters from the current node, starting with the character at the position offset and continuing for count characters. If offset plus count is greater than the number of characters in the current node, all characters from offset to the end of the string are deleted..

Parameters:
offset - The position of the first character to be deleted.
count - The number of characters to be deleted.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if this method was called on a node that is read-only and may not be modified, or the value JsDOMException.INDEX_SIZE_ERR if the offset or count argument is negative, or offset is greater than the length of the current node. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

insertData

public final void insertData(java.lang.Number offset,
                             java.lang.String arg)

Inserts the specified string into the text of the current node at the specified character offset.

This method inserts the specified string arg into the text of the current node at the specified position offset.

Parameters:
offset - The character position within the current node at which the string is to be inserted.
arg - The string to insert.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if this method was called on a node that is read-only and may not be modified, or the value JsDOMException.INDEX_SIZE_ERR if the offset argument is negative or greater than the length of the current node. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

replaceData

public final void replaceData(java.lang.Number offset,
                              java.lang.Number count,
                              java.lang.String arg)

Replaces the characters starting at the specified character offset and continuing for the specified number of characters with the specified string.

This method replaces count characters starting at position offset within the string arg. If the sum of offset and count is greater than the length of the current node, all characters from offset on are replaced.

Parameters:
offset - The character position within the current node at which the replacement is to begin.
count - The number of characters to be replaced.
arg - The string that replaces the characters specified by offset and count.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if this method was called on a node that is read-only and may not be modified, or the value JsDOMException.INDEX_SIZE_ERR if the offset or count argument is negative, or offset is greater than the length of the current node. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

substringData

public final java.lang.String substringData(java.lang.Number offset,
                                            java.lang.Number count)

Returns a copy of the text starting at the specified character offset and continuing for the specified number of characters.

This method extracts the substring that starts at position offset and continues for count characters from the text of the current node. This method is useful only when the amount of text contained by the current node is larger than the maximum number of characters that can fit in a string in a browser's JavaScript implementation. In this case, a JavaScript program cannot use the data property of the node directly and must instead work with shorter substrings of the node's text. This situation is unlikely to arise in practice.

Parameters:
offset - The position of the first character to be returned.
count - The number of characters in the substring to be returned.
Returns:
A string that consists of count characters of the current node starting with the character at position offset.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.DOMSTRING_SIZE_ERR if specified range of text is too long to fit into a string in the browser's JavaScript implementation, or the value JsDOMException.INDEX_SIZE_ERR if the offset argument is negative or greater than the length of the current node. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.
